unnormalised: ## Navigating the Nine-Month Marathon: A Humorous Guide to Obstetrics and Gynecology
normalised: ## Navigating the Nine-Month Marathon: A Humorous Guide to Obstetrics and Gynecology

unnormalised: So, you’ve decided to embark on the "miracle of life" journey, eh? Buckle up, buttercup, because the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology (OB/GYN) is about to become your new reality. Forget binge-watching Netflix; get ready for binge-reading about Braxton Hicks contractions, episiotomies, and the joys of leaking bodily fluids at inopportune moments. Don’t worry, though, we'll navigate this together, with a healthy dose of humor to keep you from losing your sanity.
normalised: So, you’ve decided to embark on the "miracle of life" journey, eh? Buckle up, buttercup, because the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology (O-B slash G-Y-N) is about to become your new reality. Forget binge-watching Netflix; get ready for binge-reading about Braxton Hicks contractions, episiotomies, and the joys of leaking bodily fluids at inopportune moments. Don’t worry, though, we'll navigate this together, with a healthy dose of humor to keep you from losing your sanity.

unnormalised: First things first, find yourself a good OB/GYN. This person will be your guru, your confidante, and the holder of all the answers to questions you never thought you'd ask. If Dr. Sharma at AIIMS is accepting new patients, consider yourself lucky. Just be prepared for the mandatory pelvic exam. It’s like a surprise inspection, but instead of finding dust bunnies under your sofa, they’re checking out your cervix.
normalised: First things first, find yourself a good O-B slash G-Y-N. This person will be your guru, your confidante, and the holder of all the answers to questions you never thought you'd ask. If Doctor Sharma at A-I-I-M-S is accepting new patients, consider yourself lucky. Just be prepared for the mandatory pelvic exam. It’s like a surprise inspection, but instead of finding dust bunnies under your sofa, they’re checking out your cervix.

unnormalised: Now, let's talk about the fun stuff – prenatal appointments. Expect to pee in a cup approximately every 15 minutes. They're measuring everything from your glucose levels to your protein content, all to ensure your little one is thriving. You'll also be weighed, measured, and poked more times than a voodoo doll. And then there’s the ultrasound. It's like a sneak peek at your future roommate. Hopefully, they aren’t already giving you the side-eye.
normalised: Now, let's talk about the fun stuff – prenatal appointments. Expect to pee in a cup approximately every fifteen minutes. They're measuring everything from your glucose levels to your protein content, all to ensure your little one is thriving. You'll also be weighed, measured, and poked more times than a voodoo doll. And then there’s the ultrasound. It's like a sneak peek at your future roommate. Hopefully, they aren’t already giving you the side-eye.

unnormalised: Pregnancy symptoms? Oh, they’re a delight! Morning sickness that lasts all day, every day? Check! Heartburn that feels like a dragon is living in your chest? Check! Swollen ankles that resemble elephant feet? Double-check! But hey, at least you get to blame all your cravings on the baby. "I need a plate of pani puri at 3 AM. It's for the baby!"
normalised: Pregnancy symptoms? Oh, they’re a delight! Morning sickness that lasts all day, every day? Check! Heartburn that feels like a dragon is living in your chest? Check! Swollen ankles that resemble elephant feet? Double-check! But hey, at least you get to blame all your cravings on the baby. "I need a plate of pani puri at three A-M. It's for the baby!"

unnormalised: Delivery day is its own special kind of chaos. It’s like running a marathon, except instead of winning a medal, you get a baby. And maybe some stitches. The epidural is your best friend, by the way. Embrace it. Love it. Name your firstborn after it. Labour can last anywhere from 4 hours to 24+ hrs, sometimes more for a first-time mum! You may even require a C-section, no biggie, just a tiny little surgical procedure while you are awake. Don't worry, you won't feel a thing! (Much).
normalised: Delivery day is its own special kind of chaos. It’s like running a marathon, except instead of winning a medal, you get a baby. And maybe some stitches. The epidural is your best friend, by the way. Embrace it. Love it. Name your firstborn after it. Labour can last anywhere from four hours to twenty four plus hours, sometimes more for a first-time mum! You may even require a C-section, no biggie, just a tiny little surgical procedure while you are awake. Don't worry, you won't feel a thing! (Much).

unnormalised: Postpartum life? Well, it’s a whole new level of exhaustion. You’re running on zero sleep, covered in baby fluids, and trying to figure out how to keep a tiny human alive. But amidst the chaos, there are moments of pure, unadulterated joy. Like when your baby smiles at you for the first time, or when they finally stop crying for 5 minutes straight.
normalised: Postpartum life? Well, it’s a whole new level of exhaustion. You’re running on zero sleep, covered in baby fluids, and trying to figure out how to keep a tiny human alive. But amidst the chaos, there are moments of pure, unadulterated joy. Like when your baby smiles at you for the first time, or when they finally stop crying for five minutes straight.

unnormalised: And let's not forget about gynecology. Regular checkups are essential, ladies! Pap smears are like a party for your cervix (a slightly awkward party, but a party nonetheless). And if you experience any unusual symptoms – like itching, burning, or green discharge – don't Google it! Just call your OB/GYN. Seriously. Google will only convince you that you have some rare tropical disease. Remember those Rs. 3000 checkups are worth it in the long run.
normalised: And let's not forget about gynecology. Regular checkups are essential, ladies! Pap smears are like a party for your cervix (a slightly awkward party, but a party nonetheless). And if you experience any unusual symptoms – like itching, burning, or green discharge – don't Google it! Just call your O-B slash G-Y-N. Seriously. Google will only convince you that you have some rare tropical disease. Remember those rupees three thousand checkups are worth it in the long run.

unnormalised: So, there you have it – a humorous glimpse into the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology. It's a wild ride, filled with ups and downs, but it's also one of the most rewarding experiences you'll ever have. Now go forth and conquer, and don't forget to laugh along the way. You'll need it! Oh and prepone that Gynaecologist apppointment you have been putting off, its important!
normalised: So, there you have it – a humorous glimpse into the world of Obstetrics and Gynecology. It's a wild ride, filled with ups and downs, but it's also one of the most rewarding experiences you'll ever have. Now go forth and conquer, and don't forget to laugh along the way. You'll need it!
